Pizarro: ‚ÄúAchieving those goals, of course, is no small task. It‚Äôs going to require a massive economy-wide effort. We need many resources and stakeholders to address climate change, but electric utilities are central figures.‚Äú @townhallLA

Pizarro: ‚ÄúThis is not just something that our governor or legislative leaders want; polls from the highly respected Public Policy Institute of California consistently show that nearly 70% of California residents support these policies.‚Äù @townhallLA

Pizarro: ‚ÄúCalifornia has set ambitious climate change goals ‚Äì to reduce greenhouse gases by 40 percent from 1990 levels by 2030, which is only 12 years from now. Our State is setting an example for the nation and the world.‚Äù @townhallLA

Pizarro: ‚ÄúEdison International joined other U.S. businesses, universities, and state and local leaders in signing an open letter to the international community demonstrating our support for the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement.‚Äú @townhallLA

Pizarro: ‚ÄúElectric companies in California are at the leading edge of the climate challenge. Addressing climate change is now a major goal of our industry. That‚Äôs because utilities are in the best position to move the needle by adopting clean energy.‚Äù @townhallla
Pizarro: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to sound alarmist. But let‚Äôs be realistic: We are past the point of debate. It‚Äôs time to take real action to deal with climate change and its devastating effects.‚Äù

Pizarro: ‚ÄúWildfires are gaining in intensity, frequency and unpredictability, with more severe consequences than ever. In fact, 8 of the 20 most destructive fires in California history have occurred since 2015.‚Äù @townhallLA

Pizarro: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just California. More than 100 large fires are currently burning in the Western states, and so far, more than 6 million acres have burned nationwide in 2018, an area larger than New Hampshire.‚Äù @townhallLA

Edison CEO Pedro Pizarro at @townhallLA ‚ÄúClimate change remains a topic of political debate. But in California, it‚Äôs not just a scientific or political issue. It‚Äôs something we are living with already, most dramatically and tragically in the form of wildfires.‚Äú

Ford's John Viera: China likely will be the biggest driver of EV expansion due to its air quality and energy security concerns. #EEI2014

... GM's Fletcher: Car buying a very emotional decision, we're still trying to figure out how to connect with consumers about EVs. #EEI2014

... Including lower maintenance costs, total cost of ownership, savings on fuel. #EEI2014
Craver: Buyers not sold on financial, economic benefits of EVs. Utilities included. We have to make the case for real $ savings... #EEI2014
Craver: EVs still a novelty item. Keys to more widespread adoption are public awareness and education. #EEI2014

Viera: Our Ford electric vehicles have very high customer satisfaction. EVs are fun to drive, plus you save a lot of money on gas. #EEI2014

... While preserving safety, reliability and affordability. #EEI2014

Craver: Utilities have always been good problem solvers. But now must exercise new muscles--flexibility, creativity, innovation. #EEI2014
